data.title: Death Is Called Engelchen (1963)
data.meta_description: Pavel is a Czech partisan fighter in the waning days of the war. Just as peace is declared, Pavel is shot in the spine and sent to the hospital emergency ward. As he fades in and out of consciousness, he recalls the events that led to his participation in the underground. Holding German occupation commander Engelchen responsible for all the horrors and deprivations heaped upon his comrades, Pavel is kept alive by the possibility of recovering and exacting vengeance upon the Nazi officer - no matter how long it takes.
data.text:
A Czech war film focusing on local partisan fighters during WWII, this is the antithesis of a patriotic celebratory war film. Rather it focuses on the ambiguous experiences of Pavel (Jan Kačer), a partisan fighter: the mistakes made on both sides, the distortions caused by hatred of the enemy, This is all recalled in flashbacks after Pavel is paralyzed by a back injury, laying face down on a hospital bed.

Directors Ján Kádár and Elmer Klos - most famous for the film they made together The Shop on Main Street the following year - are technically of an older generation than the Czech New Wave directors. But there are many New Wave features here - the creative cinematography, the haunting…

Death is Called Engelchen follows Czechoslovak partisan Pavel as he tackles with psychological trauma and serious physical injuries after the German withdrawal.

It's a soul torturing film that goes deep into the gruesome effect war has on individual people as their forced to commit horrid acts to comabt the enemy, acts which they can't live with and which haunt them.

The editing was astonishing, like I've never seen before! The way it's able to transition between flashbacks almost seamlessly makes it feel like the viewer is experiencing Paval's memories with him. There's also a riveting sequence shot entirely from Paval's POV which is quite frankly, pretty fucking awesome

It's portrayal of German soldiers is also something else that needs to…
